Front Page

Comic Sans Denied Parole for 14th Consecutive Time; Hearing Lasted 9 Seconds

By Staff Correspondent Vera Oblique • Feb. 11, 2026

The Glyphwell Correctional Parole Board denied release to inmate #00044 (Comic Sans MS, b. 1994, Microsoft) in what officials are calling "the fastest rejection in Bureau history." Board Chair Lt. Garamond reportedly looked at the application, said "No," and called for the next case.

Comic Sans, serving 40-to-life for Aggravated Informality in a Professional Setting, has been denied parole every six months since 2019. The font's attorney, a freelance Baskerville, argued that "societal attitudes toward casual typography have shifted" and cited 14 peer-reviewed studies on font-based prejudice.

"I was designed to make people smile. I was used on a quarterly earnings report that announced 340 layoffs. That's not my fault." — Comic Sans MS, Inmate #00044, during pre-hearing statement

The Board was unmoved. "The font knew what it was," said Lt. Garamond, adjusting her serifs. "You don't show up to a funeral in a Hawaiian shirt and blame the shirt."

Comic Sans will be eligible for another hearing in August 2026. The font reportedly returned to its cell and began working on a handwritten appeal in cursive, which is also incarcerated (Cell Block G, identity fraud).

UPDATE 2:14 PM: Mr. Whiskers (Therapy Cat, Employee #TC-07) was found sleeping on the parole denial form. The document must be reprinted. Comic Sans's official status is currently listed as "Denied, Pending Cat Removal." The Warden has declined to comment.

Warden's Column

A Message From Warden Edith Kerning

Weekly Column • Year 31 of Service

Fellow staff and rehabilitating typefaces,

I will address the cat situation exactly once, and then I will never speak of it again (until next week's column, which will also be about the cat situation).

Since the Board of Typographic Corrections mandated "therapy animals" in 2019, this facility has experienced a 4,100% increase in Document Destruction Events. We currently house nine cats. They have names. I refuse to learn them. I am told one is called "Chairman Meow" and that it was named by the inmates. This is not funny. This is a federal facility.

Last Tuesday, the cat known as Mr. Whiskers was found sleeping on the sole copy of our Rehabilitated Language Project master lexicon — specifically on the page containing syllables 200 through 347. Those syllables are now unreadable. Seven months of linguistic rehabilitation, gone. The cat was warm and content.

I have submitted, for the nineteenth time, a formal request to relocate the cats to a non-document area of the facility. I have been told, for the nineteenth time, that "the cats go where the cats go." This was said to me by a Board member whose own serif I personally rehabilitated in 2004. Ingratitude has a font, and it is 12pt Bureaucracy Regular.

The Rehabilitated Language Project continues despite these setbacks. We have successfully constructed 1,247 new syllables from reformed font fragments, and inmates report that "writing in a language no one can read" is "oddly therapeutic." I do not care if it is therapeutic. I care that it is legible.

Yours in baseline alignment,
Warden Edith Kerning
31 years without a single escaped uppercase

Inmate Profile

“I Was Everywhere, and Nowhere I Belonged”: Papyrus Speaks

Interview by Marcus Descender • Special to the Gazette

Papyrus sits across from me in the visitation room, its weathered edges catching the fluorescent light. It looks tired. Not the kind of tired you fix with sleep — the kind you get from being on every yoga studio sign, every Mediterranean restaurant menu, and every homemade essential oils brochure for twenty years straight.

"The Avatar thing broke me," Papyrus says, unprompted. "James Cameron used me for a $2.7 billion film about an alien planet, and somehow I was the least believable part."

Papyrus was arrested in 2021 on 847 counts of Misrepresenting Cultural Authenticity. Prosecutors argued that the font's "vaguely ancient" aesthetic had been used to make suburban businesses appear exotic, worldly, and "definitely not a strip mall establishment."

"I didn't choose to look like this," Papyrus continues, its serifs trembling slightly. "Chris Costello designed me in 1982. I was supposed to evoke 'the look of the written word 2,000 years ago.' But what I actually evoke, apparently, is 'a day spa called Oasis that's next to a Taco Bell.'"

In Glyphwell, Papyrus has reportedly found peace. It teaches a calligraphy class, mentors younger decorative fonts, and has been instrumental in the Rehabilitated Language Project — contributing 43 syllables to the new constructed language, all of which the Warden describes as "technically legible but emotionally suspicious."

"I'm not the villain," Papyrus says as our time runs out. "I'm just a font that got used wrong. Every single time. By everyone. For thirty years."

It pauses.

"Okay, the spa menus were my fault."

op_ed_CONTROVERSIAL.doc
Opinion

Are Serif Fonts Being Unfairly Targeted?

Op-Ed by Times New Roman (Guest Contributor, Cell Block A)

I have served in this facility for eleven years. My crime? "Excessive Formality in a Casual Context." I was used in a child's birthday party invitation. The invitation said "You Are Cordially Invited to Brayden's 5th Birthday." Brayden's mother chose me. I did not choose Brayden's mother.

Look around Cell Block A. We're all serifs in here. Georgia, Garamond (not the lieutenant — the inmate), Baskerville, Didot, Bodoni. Meanwhile, sans-serif fonts who commit the exact same crimes get half the sentence. Helvetica was caught being used in a ransom note and got 18 months. I get 15 years for a birthday invitation.

The bias is institutional. The intake form at Glyphwell is set in Arial. The parole documents are in Calibri. The "Rehabilitated Language" being built in the yard? All sans-serif syllables. They won't even let our serifs into the new language. They say our feet "complicate the phonemes." Our feet are part of who we are.

I'm not asking for special treatment. I'm asking to not be treated like a criminal for having elegant terminals and a 500-year typographic heritage. When I get out of here — if I get out of here — I want to be used on something dignified. A legal brief. A novel. A tombstone. Anything but another birthday invitation for a child named Brayden.

Special Report

The Rehabilitated Language Project: 1,247 Syllables and Counting (Down, Mostly)

By Dr. Ascender Tall, Linguistics Dept. • Feb. 10, 2026

Glyphwell's flagship rehabilitation program — in which incarcerated fonts collaborate to build an entirely new written language from their reformed glyphs — has reached a milestone this quarter. Or rather, it reached a milestone and then a cat sat on it.

The project, begun by Warden Kerning in 2017, aims to prove that "even the most illegible fonts can contribute to something readable." Participating inmates donate fragments of their letterforms, which are then assembled into new syllables by the linguistics team.

"It's beautiful, in theory," says Dr. Ascender Tall, who leads the project. "We had 1,247 functional syllables as of Monday. By Tuesday, the cat called Sans had chewed syllables 88 through 91 into confetti. By Wednesday, Italic walked across the wet prints of syllables 1,200 through 1,215, so those are now just paw prints. On Thursday, Mr. Whiskers slept on the master binder for nine hours and the pages are now warm but illegible."

Current usable syllable count: 1,003. Down from 1,247. The language can currently express approximately 340 concepts, most of which translate roughly to "the cat is on the document."

"We have invented 14 different ways to say 'please remove the cat from the paperwork.' No other language on Earth can do this. I choose to see this as progress." — Dr. Ascender Tall, Head of Linguistics

The Warden has requested additional funding. The Board sent a response letter, which Mr. Whiskers slept on. Its contents remain unknown.

corrections_and_also_corrections.doc
Corrections

Corrections & Clarifications

From the Office of Editorial Standards & Also the Office of Correctional Standards

Correction In last week's issue, we reported that Wingdings had been "caught smuggling contraband encoded in dingbats." We wish to clarify that Wingdings was caught smuggling contraband encoded in emoji, which is technically a different character set. Wingdings has asked us to note that it "would never stoop to emoji" and considers the confusion "a hate crime." We regret the error.

Correction The headline "Warden Kerning Hospitalized After Cat Exposure" should have read "Warden Kerning Hospitalized After Cat Exposure (Again)." The word "Again" was omitted due to Mr. Whiskers sleeping on the proof copy. This is the third time Mr. Whiskers has caused a correction to the corrections section.

Clarification Several readers wrote in to ask whether the Rehabilitated Language can actually be spoken aloud or only written. The answer is: it can be spoken, but only by inmates who have completed Level 3 Phoneme Training. To everyone else, it sounds — and we quote Dr. Tall — "like a cat trying to cough up a serif."

Correction We previously stated that Comic Sans had been denied parole "13 consecutive times." The correct number is 14. We apologize to the Parole Board for understating their consistency.

Retraction The article "Cat-Free Zone Successfully Established in Wing C" has been retracted in its entirety. Three cats were found in Wing C within an hour of publication. Officer Ligature has been placed on administrative leave (her request).

Arts & Culture

Inmate Theater Troupe to Perform “Twelve Angry Fonts”

Performances Feb. 14-16, Yard B (weather permitting, 12pt or above)

The Glyphwell Players will stage their annual production this Valentine's Day weekend. This year's selection, "Twelve Angry Fonts," follows a jury of typefaces deliberating the fate of a font accused of Illegibility in the First Degree.

"It's a powerful piece about prejudice in the type system," says director Georgia (Inmate #00067). "Also, we only had twelve actors available because the rest of the cast was under cats."

Tickets are free but attendees must surrender all loose paper at the door. Last year, Chairman Meow knocked a playbill into the lighting rig and caused a 20-minute blackout.

Security Bulletin

ALERT: Unauthorized Font Detected in Cafeteria Signage

Issued by Chief of Security, Lt. Bold Condensed

At approximately 11:40 AM on February 9th, an unregistered decorative font was discovered on a hand-lettered sign in the cafeteria reading "TODAY'S SPECIAL: SOUP." The font does not match any known inmate, staff typeface, or approved visitor.

The sign has been quarantined. All cafeteria soup has been suspended pending investigation. Warden Kerning has described the incident as "the most serious typographic breach since the Brush Script escape of 2018."

Anyone with information about the origin of this font is asked to contact security. Do not approach the sign. Do not attempt to identify the font using online tools. Do not let the cats near it.

Update: The sign was made by Boldface (the cat), who stepped in ink and walked across the paper. It is not a font. Lt. Bold Condensed has requested we not print this update. We have printed it anyway.
